awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a triple-quadrupole ICP-MS and sample introduction hardware for multidisciplinary research and teaching
awd_abstract_narration:
This Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) program award will support the acquisition of a modern triple-quadrupole inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometer (TQ-ICP-MS) and three dedicated sample processing and introduction systems for research and teaching in the Institute of Marine Science’s Marine Analytical Laboratory at the University of California, Santa Cruz. This suite of instruments will enable novel multidisciplinary analytical work by faculty, researchers, and students that will contribute to a more refined understanding of diverse processes in Earth, ocean, and planetary sciences, and environmental toxicology. The new facility will amplify the campus commitment to student social mobility and increased diversity in STEM by providing state-of-the-art instrumentation for practical training in the context of undergraduate and graduate coursework and research. Laboratory PIs actively engage with the AGU Bridge program (Ocean Sciences), NSF-ICER GEOPAths - IMPACT (Earth and Planetary Sciences), and the UCSC STEM Diversity Program, which fund cutting-edge research opportunities for underrepresented students.  

TQ-ICP-MS systems combine the sensitivity, scan speed, and dynamic range of modern single quadrupole ICP-MS with a quadrupole - reaction cell - quadrupole configuration that enables unambiguous chemical and physical resolution of many of the most challenging isobaric interferences. The three dedicated sample introductions systems include: (1) a gas chromatograph speciation analysis of organometallics (e.g., Hg)  in the marine and terrestrial environments; (2) an ESI prepFAST IC for high-throughput metal speciation (e.g. As, Cr, Se) and total metal analysis for environmental toxicology research; and (3) an ESI seaFAST for automated analysis of ultra-trace elements in seawater. The TQ-ICP-MS will be integrated with an existing Teledyne Analyte Excite laser ablation system and Thermo Element XR high-resolution magnetic sector ICP-MS. The laser can be operated with either ICP-MS or with both for split-stream analysis of geological and meteoritic materials for geochemical and petrochronologic research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overview

This project supported the acquisition of a state-of-the-art triple-quadrupole inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometer (ICP-MS) and associated sample introduction hardware, including an ESI seaFAST SP2 for seawater trace element preconcentration, an ESI prepFAST IC for chromatography and speciation of metals in environmental and biological media, and an Agilent 8890 gas chromatograph for volatile organometallic compounds. These advanced analytical instruments enable precise and accurate measurements of trace elements and isotopes in a variety of samples, from environmental materials to biological specimens. The project will have significant impacts on research, education, and outreach in diverse scientific disciplines, including geology, oceanography, environmental science and toxicology, and archaeology.

Key Benefits and Impacts

  1. Advancing Multidisciplinary Research: The Agilent triple-quadrupole ICP-MS has become a cornerstone of research across multiple fields. Its unparalleled sensitivity and specificity allow researchers to detect and quantify elements at concentrations as low as parts per trillion. Key applications include:

    • Geological and Materials Science: Analyses of rocks, minerals, meteorites, and synthetic materials to reveal new information about the history of the Earth and Solar System and the properties of novel compounds.

    • Oceanography: Analyses of seawater and marine particles and sediments to understand the role of the ocean in global climate and environmental cycling 

    • Environmental Science: Investigations into water quality, soil contamination, and air particulate analysis to provide insights into pollution sources and environmental health.

    • Toxicology Research: Studies of trace elements in biological tissues and fluids to have advanced understanding of nutrient deficiencies and metal toxicity in humans and animals.

    • Archeology: studies of provenance, forensics, and dietary ecology using trace element concentrations and lead and strontium isotopes

  2. Enhancing Educational Opportunities: The instrument will be integrated into undergraduate and graduate curricula, offering students hands-on experience with cutting-edge technology. Formal courses and informal training through opportunities in research labs in analytical chemistry, environmental science, and geochemistry will use the new sample introduction systems and the TQ-ICP-MS. This exposure prepares students for careers in academia, industry, and government laboratories.

  3. Fostering Collaboration: The acquisition of the ICP-MS and multiple introduction systems will  strengthen partnerships among universities, government agencies, and private companies in the Monterey Bay and San Francisco Bay regions. 

Conclusions

The acquisition and installation of the new triple-quadrupole ICP-MS and sample introduction systems ensures that UCSC remains at the forefront of research and education in many disciplines. By enabling high-precision analyses across disciplines, the project will advance scientific understanding, support workforce development, and contribute to solving societal challenges. 




Last Modified: 01/20/2025
Modified by: Carl Lamborg
por.por_txt_cntn:
Overview


This project supported the acquisition of a state-of-the-art triple-quadrupole inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometer (ICP-MS) and associated sample introduction hardware, including an ESI seaFAST SP2 for seawater trace element preconcentration, an ESI prepFAST IC for chromatography and speciation of metals in environmental and biological media, and an Agilent 8890 gas chromatograph for volatile organometallic compounds. These advanced analytical instruments enable precise and accurate measurements of trace elements and isotopes in a variety of samples, from environmental materials to biological specimens. The project will have significant impacts on research, education, and outreach in diverse scientific disciplines, including geology, oceanography, environmental science and toxicology, and archaeology.


Key Benefits and Impacts




Advancing Multidisciplinary Research: The Agilent triple-quadrupole ICP-MS has become a cornerstone of research across multiple fields. Its unparalleled sensitivity and specificity allow researchers to detect and quantify elements at concentrations as low as parts per trillion. Key applications include:




Geological and Materials Science: Analyses of rocks, minerals, meteorites, and synthetic materials to reveal new information about the history of the Earth and Solar System and the properties of novel compounds.




Oceanography: Analyses of seawater and marine particles and sediments to understand the role of the ocean in global climate and environmental cycling




Environmental Science: Investigations into water quality, soil contamination, and air particulate analysis to provide insights into pollution sources and environmental health.




Toxicology Research: Studies of trace elements in biological tissues and fluids to have advanced understanding of nutrient deficiencies and metal toxicity in humans and animals.




Archeology: studies of provenance, forensics, and dietary ecology using trace element concentrations and lead and strontium isotopes






Enhancing Educational Opportunities: The instrument will be integrated into undergraduate and graduate curricula, offering students hands-on experience with cutting-edge technology. Formal courses and informal training through opportunities in research labs in analytical chemistry, environmental science, and geochemistry will use the new sample introduction systems and the TQ-ICP-MS. This exposure prepares students for careers in academia, industry, and government laboratories.




Fostering Collaboration: The acquisition of the ICP-MS and multiple introduction systems will strengthen partnerships among universities, government agencies, and private companies in the Monterey Bay and San Francisco Bay regions.




Conclusions


The acquisition and installation of the new triple-quadrupole ICP-MS and sample introduction systems ensures that UCSC remains at the forefront of research and education in many disciplines. By enabling high-precision analyses across disciplines, the project will advance scientific understanding, support workforce development, and contribute to solving societal challenges.
